en: This is Sarah Long.
zh: And this is Rich Kleinfeldt with THE MAKING OF A NATION, a VOA Special English program about the history of the United States.

en: Today, we tell about the start of the American colonies' war for independence from Britain in the late 1700s.
zh: The road to revolution lasted several years.

en: The most serious events began in 1770.
zh: War began five years later.

en: Relations between Britain and its American colonists were most tense in the colony of Massachusetts.
zh: There were protests against the British policy of taxing the colonies without giving them representation in Parliament.

en: To prevent trouble, thousands of British soldiers were sent to Boston, the biggest city in Massachusetts.
zh: On March 5, 1770, tension led to violence.

en: This is what happened.
zh: It was the end of winter, and the weather was very cold.

en: A small group of colonists began throwing rocks and pieces of ice at soldiers guarding a public building.
zh: They were joined by others, and the soldiers became frightened.

en: They fired their guns.
zh: Five colonists were killed.

en: The incident became known as the Boston Massacre.
zh: The people of Massachusetts were extremely angry.

en: The soldiers were tried in court for murder.
zh: Most were found innocent.

en: The others received minor punishments.
zh: Fearing more violence, the British Parliament cancelled most of its taxes.

en: Only the tax on tea remained.
zh: This eased some of the tensions for a while.

en: Imports of British goods increased.
zh: The colonists seemed satisfied with the situation, until a few years later.

en: That is when the Massachusetts colony once again became involved in a dispute with Britain.
zh: The trouble started because the British government wanted to help improve the business of the British East India Company.

en: That company organized all the trade between India and other countries ruled by Britain.
zh: By 1773, the company had become weak.

en: The British government decided to permit it to sell tea directly to the American colonies.
zh: The colonies would still have to pay a tea tax to Britain.

en: The Americans did not like the new plan.
zh: They felt they were being forced to buy their tea from only one company.

en: Officials in the colonies of Pennsylvania and New York sent the East India Company's ships back to Britain.
zh: In Massachusetts, things were different.

en: The British governor there wanted to collect the tea tax and enforce the law.
zh: When the ships arrived in Boston, some colonists tried to block their way.

en: The ships remained just outside the harbor without unloading their goods.
zh: On the night of December sixteenth, 1773, a group of colonists went out in a small boat.

en: They got on a British ship and threw all the tea into the water.
zh: The colonists were dressed as American Indians so the British would not recognize them, but the people of Boston knew who they were.

en: A crowd gathered to cheer them.
zh: That incident -- the night when British tea was thrown into Boston harbor -- became known as the Boston Tea Party.

en: Destroying the tea was a serious crime.
zh: The British government was angry.

en: Parliament reacted to the Boston Tea Party by punishing the whole colony of Massachusetts for the actions of a few men.
zh: It approved a series of laws that once again changed relations between the colony and Britain.

en: One of these laws closed the port of Boston until the tea was paid for.
zh: Other laws strengthened the power of the British governor and weakened the power of local colonial officials.

en: In June, 1774, the colony of Massachusetts called for a meeting of delegates from all the other colonies to consider joint action against Britain.
zh: This meeting of colonial delegates was called the First Continental Congress.

en: It was held in the city of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, in September, 1774.
zh: All the colonies except one was represented.

en: The southern colony of Georgia did not send a delegate.
zh: The delegates agreed that the British Parliament had no right to control trade with the American colonies or to make any laws that affected them.

en: They said the people of the colonies must have the right to take part in any legislative group that made laws for them.
zh: The First Continental Congress approved a series of documents that condemned all British actions in the American colonies after 1763.

en: It approved a Massachusetts proposal saying that the people could use weapons to defend their rights.
zh: It also organized a Continental Association to boycott British goods and to stop all exports to any British colony or to Britain itself.

en: Local committees were created to enforce the boycott.
zh: One of the delegates to this First Continental Congress was John Adams of Massachusetts.

en: Many years later, he said that by the time the meeting was held, the American Revolution had already begun.
zh: Britain's King George the Second announced that the New England colonies were in rebellion.

en: Parliament made the decision to use troops against Massachusetts in January, 1775.
zh: The people of Massachusetts formed a provincial assembly and began training men to fight.

en: Soon, groups of armed men were doing military exercises in towns all around Massachusetts and in other colonies, too.
zh: British officers received their orders in April, 1775.

en: By that time, the colonists had been gathering weapons in the town of Concord, about thirty kilometers west of Boston.
zh: The British forces were ordered to seize the weapons.

en: But the colonists knew they were coming and were prepared.
zh: Years later, Henry Wadsworth Longfellow wrote a poem about what happened.

en: The poem tells about the actions of Paul Revere, one of three men who helped warn the colonial troops that the British were coming:
zh: Listen my children and you shall hear

en: Of the midnight ride of Paul Revere.
zh: On the eighteenth of April in Seventy-five

en: Hardly a man is now alive
zh: Who remembers that famous day and year.

en: He said to his friend, "If the British march
zh: By land or sea from the town tonight

en: Hang a lantern aloft in the belfry arch
zh: Of the North Church tower as a signal light, --

en: One if by land, and two if by sea;
zh: And I on the opposite shore will be,

en: Ready to ride and spread the alarm
zh: Through every Middlesex village and farm

en: For the country folk to be up and to arm."
zh: When the British reached the town of Lexington, they found it protected by about seventy colonial troops.

en: These troops were called "Minute Men" because they had been trained to fight with only a minute's warning.
zh: Guns were fired.

en: Eight colonists were killed.
zh: No one knows who fired the first shot in that first battle of the American Revolution.

en: Each side accused the other.
zh: But the meaning was very clear.

en: It was called "the shot heard round the world."
zh: From Lexington, the British marched to Concord, where they destroyed whatever supplies the colonists had not been able to save.

en: Other colonial troops rushed to the area.
zh: A battle at Concord's north bridge forced the British to march back to Boston.

en: It was the first day of America's war for independence.
zh: When it was over, almost three hundred British troops had been killed.

en: Fewer than one hundred Americans had died.
zh: The British troops had marched in time with their drummers and pipers.

en: The musicians had played a song called "Yankee Doodle."  The British invented the song to insult the Americans.
zh: They said a Yankee Doodle was a man who did not know how to fight.

en: After the early battles of the revolution, the Americans said they were glad to be Yankee Doodles.
zh: Following the battles at Lexington and Concord, the Massachusetts government organized a group that captured Fort Ticonderoga on Lake Champlain in New York State.

en: The other colonies began sending troops to help.
zh: And another joint colonial meeting was called:  the Second Continental Congress.

en: That will be our story next week.

en: This is Sarah Long.
zh: And this is Rich Kleinfeldt.
